message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in joints. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can reduce inflammation and pain associated with gout. Probenecid is used for chronic gout to increase the excretion of uric acid into the urine. Oral methylprednisolone and meloxicam are also used for acute gout but are less effective than nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Colchicine and celecoxib can also be used for acute gout, but diclofenac is the most appropriate initial treatment option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in the joints. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can help relieve pain and inflammation in the affected joint. Probenecid is used for chronic treatment of gout, while colchicine and celecoxib can also be used for acute attacks of gout, but they are not the first-line options in this case. Oral methylprednisolone is a steroid that can also help reduce inflammation, but it is not the first-line treatment for gout.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with acute gouty arthritis, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can help relieve pain and inflammation associated with gout. Probenecid is used for chronic gout management, while colchicine is commonly used for acute gout treatment, but is not the best option for this patient due to his hypertension. Oral methylprednisolone may also be used as an alternative to NSAIDs, but is not listed as an option in the answer choices. The combination of colchicine and celecoxib may increase the risk of cardiovascular events and is not recommended in patients with cardiovascular disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described symptoms suggest gout, which is a type of arthritis caused by the buildup of uric acid crystals in the joints. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can help relieve pain and inflammation in gout. Probenecid, colchicine, and celecoxib are also used in the treatment of gout but are not the most appropriate option in this scenario. Oral methylprednisolone can be used for acute gout attacks but is typically reserved for cases where NSAIDs or colchicine are contraindicated or ineffective, or for patients with multiple joints affected or severe gout. Meloxicam is also an NSAID but not as effective for gout as diclofenac.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with gout, which is caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in joints. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help relieve pain and inflammation associated with gout. Probenecid is used to prevent gout attacks by reducing the levels of uric acid in the blood. Oral methylprednisolone and meloxicam can also reduce inflammation and pain, but are not specific to gout. Colchicine and celecoxib are also used for gout treatment, but diclofenac is a more appropriate choice for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest gout, which is caused by the accumulation of urate crystals in the joint. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first-line therapy for gout attacks, and diclofenac is an NSAID. Probenecid is used for chronic gout management, and colchicine and celecoxib are alternative treatments for acute gout attacks but are not the first-line therapy. Oral methylprednisolone may be used in severe cases or if the patient cannot tolerate NSAIDs, but it is not the initial choice in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest gout, a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and other tissues. Diclofenac, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, is commonly used to treat acute gout attacks. Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that increases uric acid excretion and is used for chronic gout management. Oral methylprednisolone and meloxicam can also be used for acute gout attacks. Colchicine and celecoxib are alternatives for gout treatment, but diclofenac is the most appropriate choice according to the information provided in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the swelling, redness, and tenderness, suggest gout. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) and can be used to treat gout. Probenecid alone is used for chronic gout management, while oral methylprednisolone and meloxicam and colchicine and celecoxib are used for acute gout attacks, but they are not the first-line treatment.

We refer to Medscape for help. The symptoms suggest acute gout, and the most common treatment is NSAIDs such as diclofenac. Probenecid is used to prevent gout attacks, while colchicine targets acute gout attacks as well but is usually used in combination with NSAIDs or corticosteroids. Methylprednisolone and celecoxib are also used in the treatment of gout, but the first-line treatment is NSAIDs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of gout, which is a type of arthritis caused by high levels of uric acid in the blood. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help relieve pain and inflammation in gout patients. Probenecid is used as a second-line therapy to treat gout, while colchicine and celecoxib are not commonly used as first-line treatments for acute gout attacks. Oral methylprednisolone and meloxicam may be used in certain situations, but are not typically the primary treatment for acute gout attacks.
